metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: AngularJS Select Boxes
AngularJS lets you create dropdown lists based on items in an array, or an object.
content.html: AngularJS lets you create dropdown lists based on items in an array, or an object.

content.text: Creating a Select Box Using ng-options
If you want to create a dropdown list, based on an object or an array in AngularJS, you should use the ng-options directive:
content.html: If you want to create a dropdown list, based on an object or an array in AngularJS, you should use the ng-options directive:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<select ng-model="selectedName" 
    ng-options="x for x in names">

ng-model="selectedName" 
    ng-options="x for x in names"

syntax_highlighting.text:
<select ng-model="selectedName" 
    ng-options="x for x in names">

ng-model="selectedName" 
    ng-options="x for x in names"

content.code_html:
<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">

<select ng-model="selectedName" ng-options="x for x in names">
</select>

</div>

<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);
app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
  $scope.names = ["Emil", "Tobias", "Linus"];
});
</script>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<select ng-model="selectedName" 
    ng-options="x for x in names">

ng-model="selectedName" 
    ng-options="x for x in names"

content.text: ng-options vs ng-repeat
You can also use the ng-repeat directive to make the same dropdown list:
content.html: You can also use the ng-repeat directive to make the same dropdown list:

content.code_html:
<select>
  <option ng-repeat="x in names">{{x}}</option>
</select>

content.text: Because the ng-repeat directive repeats a block of HTML code for each item in an array, it can be used to create options in a dropdown list, but the ng-options directive was made especially for filling a dropdown list with options.
content.html: Because the ng-repeat directive repeats a block of HTML code for each item in an array, it can be used to create options in a dropdown list, but the ng-options directive was made especially for filling a dropdown list with options.

content.text: What Do I Use?
You can use both the ng-repeat directive and the ng-options directive:
content.html: You can use both the ng-repeat directive and the ng-options directive:

content.text: Assume you have an array of objects:
content.html: Assume you have an array of objects:

content.code_html:
$scope.cars = [
  {model : "Ford Mustang", color : "red"},
  {model : "Fiat 500", color : "white"},
  {model : "Volvo XC90", color : "black"}
];

<select ng-model="selectedCar">
  <option ng-repeat="x in cars" value="{{x.model}}">{{x.model}}</option>
</select>

<h1>You selected: {{selectedCar}}</h1>

content.text: When using the value as an object, use ng-value insead of value :
content.html: When using the value as an object, use ng-value insead of value:

content.code_html:
<select ng-model="selectedCar">
  <option ng-repeat="x in cars" ng-value="{{x}}">{{x.model}}</option>
</select>

<h1>You selected a {{selectedCar.color}} {{selectedCar.model}}</h1>

syntaxHighlighting.text: <select ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="x.model for x in cars">
ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="x.model for x in cars"

syntax_highlighting.text: <select ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="x.model for x in cars">
ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="x.model for x in cars"

content.code_html:
<select ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="x.model for x in cars">
</select>

<h1>You selected: {{selectedCar.model}}</h1>
<p>Its color is: {{selectedCar.color}}</p>

syntax_highlighting_data.text: <select ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="x.model for x in cars">
ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="x.model for x in cars"

content.text: When the selected value is an object, it can hold more information, and your application can be more flexible.
content.html: When the selected value is an object, it can hold more information, and your application can be more flexible.

content.text: We will use the ng-options directive in this tutorial.
content.html: We will use the ng-options directive in this tutorial.

content.text: The Data Source as an Object
In the previous examples the data source was an array, but we can also use an object.
content.html: In the previous examples the data source was an array, but we can also use an object.

content.text: Assume you have an object with key-value pairs:
content.html: Assume you have an object with key-value pairs:

content.code_html:
$scope.cars = {
  car01 : "Ford",
  car02 : "Fiat",
  car03 : "Volvo"
};

content.text: The expression in the ng-options attribute is a bit different for objects:
content.html: The expression in the ng-options attribute is a bit different for objects:

syntaxHighlighting.text: <select ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="x for (x, y) in cars">
ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="x for (x, y) in cars"

syntax_highlighting.text: <select ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="x for (x, y) in cars">
ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="x for (x, y) in cars"

content.code_html:
<select ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="x for (x, y) in cars">
</select>

<h1>You selected: {{selectedCar}}</h1>

syntax_highlighting_data.text: <select ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="x for (x, y) in cars">
ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="x for (x, y) in cars"

content.text: The selected value will always be the value in a key- value pair.
content.html: The selected value will always be the value in a key-value pair.

content.text: The value in a key- value pair can also be an object:
content.html: The value in a key-value pair can also be an object:

content.code_html:
$scope.cars = {
  car01 : {brand : "Ford", model : "Mustang", color : "red"},
  car02 : {brand : "Fiat", model : "500", color : "white"},
  car03 : {brand : "Volvo", model : "XC90", color : "black"}
};

content.text: The options in the dropdown list does not have to be the key in a key -value pair, it can also be the value, or a property of the value object:
content.html: The options in the dropdown list does not have to be the key in a key-value pair, it can also be the value, or a property of the value object:

syntaxHighlighting.text: <select ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="y.brand for (x, y) in cars">
ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="y.brand for (x, y) in cars"

syntax_highlighting.text: <select ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="y.brand for (x, y) in cars">
ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="y.brand for (x, y) in cars"

content.code_html:
<select ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="y.brand for (x, y) in cars">
</select>

syntax_highlighting_data.text: <select ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="y.brand for (x, y) in cars">
ng-model="selectedCar" ng-options="y.brand for (x, y) in cars"
